Title: It's complicated: Tier-based adoption barriers to in-home fish consumption of indonesian urban consumers
Affiliations: Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan No. 9Jakarta  11480, Indonesia; Faculty of Fisheries and Marine Science, Bogor Agricultural University, Raya Dramaga, Bogor  16680, Indonesia; Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan No. 9Jakarta  11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Maulana, A.E., Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan No. 9Jakarta  11480, Indonesia; Diniah, Faculty of Fisheries and Marine Science, Bogor Agricultural University, Raya Dramaga, Bogor  16680, Indonesia; Setiawan, D.P., Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, K. H. Syahdan No. 9Jakarta  11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to identify barriers to the adoption of in-home fish consumption by consumers in developing countries. The results of this study provide a timely understanding of fish consumption behavior that will help developing countries create more effective and efficient fish consumption promotion campaigns. The complexity of the problem of fish menu adoption is mapped and a strategy for campaign programs is proposed. The consumer expression “it’s complicated” conveys multiple meanings, as discovered by the ethnographic study in this paper. The various barriers that appear at each stage of the consumer’s daily journey constitute a tier-based, hierarchical set of layered barriers. Hence, trying to solve this problem with a simple and superficial marketing communication strategy will not result in a significant increase in fish consumption. Some of the fish consumption adoption barriers found during the study are not completely new and some repeat the results of previous studies. This study also presents the discovery of certain variables that have not been previously discussed. We provide a tier-based adoption barrier model of in-home fish consumption to explain why fish consumption is not growing significantly in developing countries, despite the notable budget spent on marketing communication activities. © 2019, BIOFLUX SRL. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Adoption barriers; Consumer; Ethnography; Fish consumption
Funding Text 1: Acknowledgements. Authors: Bagus Wicaksono K.C., Handranata Y.W., Setiawan D.P., Dewi
Title: Brand image analysis of online shopping sites in Indonesia: A case study in Bina nusantara university
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Bagus Wicaksono, K.C., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia; Handranata, Y.W., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia; Setiawan, D.P., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia; Dewi, Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Alam Sutera, Tangerang, Indonesia
Abstract: The aim of this study was to show differences in brand images of online shopping sites, namely Lazada, Tokopedia and Bukalapak based on six factors: attributes, benefits, culture, value, personality and users. Data is obtained from questionnaires distributed to respondents from Bina Nusantara University students. The study period was from March to November 2016. Data was analysed using ANOVA. Results showed differences in terms of attributes, culture and value except personality. These results can be useful for new or current companies that already have or about to create new online shopping sites to enhance their brand image and differentiate their online shopping site. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Attributes; Brand image; Culture; Online shopping sites; Value

Authors: Halim E., Setiawan D.P., Novela E.S.
Title: Factors affect quality of SMEs' online marketing website based on DeLone and McLean Model
Source title: Proceedings of 2016 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2016
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Halim, E., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Setiawan, D.P., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Novela, E.S., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The research was conducted to find factors that affect quality of SMEs' online marketing website. The research's result will be useful to give recommendation on online marketing that used by franchisor. This research used DeLone & McLean Model with questionnaire to 103 students who have had an experience in buying online. Respondents were chosen using Simple Random Sampling Method. Data were analysed using SMART PLS after we built the Research Model. Missing data and outliers have been resolved. We found that the fast respond time, availability information when it was needed, and fast respond on service were the most important factors in quality of SMEs' online marketing website. For future research, we can add about the payment and delivery services factors. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: buying online; e-commerce; online marketing; SME; website quality
Index Keywords: Information management; Marketing; Websites; buying online; Delivery service; Missing data; Online marketing; Research models; Respond time; Simple random sampling; Website quality; Electronic commerce

Authors: Setiawan D., Khayam U., Zoro R.
Title: Overvoltages and insulation coordination on 150 kV substation in South Sumatera, Indonesia
Source title: Proceedings - ICPERE 2014: 2nd IEEE Conference on Power Engineering and Renewable Energy 2014
Affiliations: Lightning Research Center, School of Electrical Engineering and Informatics, Bandung Institute of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Setiawan, D., Lightning Research Center, School of Electrical Engineering and Informatics, Bandung Institute of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia; Khayam, U., Lightning Research Center, School of Electrical Engineering and Informatics, Bandung Institute of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia; Zoro, R., Lightning Research Center, School of Electrical Engineering and Informatics, Bandung Institute of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia
Abstract: Most of the substation in Indonesia has to be check again the performance in overvoltage protection, the use of insulation coordination according to the standard IEC 71-1 has to be applied to the substation. 150 kV Teluk Betung substation in South Sumatera is one of the substation chosen to be observed and studied. The study is being done by observing the number equipment BIL etc. Analysis and evaluation of insulation coordination aims to create a system that are parts, each one and with each other have the insulation endurance that in any operating condition, the electricity supply quality can be achieved technically and economically. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Arrester; Basic Insulation Level (BIL); Conducting insulator; Insulation coordinationi; Transient Overvoltage
Index Keywords: Electric insulation coordination; Electrolysis; Energy policy; Insulation; Quality control; Analysis and evaluation; Arrester; Conducting insulator; Electricity supply; Insulation level; Operating condition; Over-voltages; Transient over-voltage; Surge protection
